instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3662: What is 820-3662? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no boot/chime
threads.message:
Apparently, beer was spilt on this and it has several areas with corrosion.
When it arrived nothing happened at all no green light etc.

Have now got it to fanspin and cpu gets hot but no boot/chime, <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> measures 1.69v 

Sometimes when i plug it in the fan spins for about 10 secs then goes off and starts spinning again and remains spinning

any ideas?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no boot/chime
threads.message: Yeah that's gonna suck. Corrosion somewhere or under some chip. Or in worst case the CPU is dead if there was corrosion around CPU power supply area.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no boot/chime
threads.message: If you looked the board over good at this point and don't see anything else obvious, then it might save time to run it through the sonic cleaner.
